67056SMMTR3INDU	1311209458999	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - HALSTEAD	300 INDUSTRIAL RD	HALSTEAD	HARVEY	KS	67056			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						38.00414	-97.52148	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 3792WRGNSP3111M	1311209459128	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS, INC. - KNOXVILLE	3111 MCCLURE LANE	KNOXVILLE	KNOX	TN	37920			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						35.95282	-83.86058	122695240								ERGON  INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

BMC Holdings, Inc. (BMC), a subsidiary of Terra Industries, Inc. (Terra), owned and operated a chemical manufacturing facility in Beaumont, TX from 1992 to 2008.  Effective January 1, 2009 Terra sold BMC to Eastman Chemical Company (Eastman).  In December 2009 Eastman issued a News Release of their decision to terminate business opportunities at the Beaumont Facility.  In April 2011, Eastman sold the Beaumont Facility to Pandora Methanol LLC (Pandora), which at that time Pandora was owned by Janus Methanol (Janus) and OCI.  In November 2011, OCI acquired 100% ownership of the BMC assets.  BMC and Terra understand that the Beaumont Facility is in the process of a name change to OCI North America.  When Eastman purchased BMC from Terra, a service agreement/contract was signed to lease certain of the terminal assets back to Terra/BMC for continuing operation as a methanol terminal.  This agreement/contract continued in effect when Pandora purchased the Beaumont Facility from Eastman. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. In March of 2012 the company announced a forth coming down sizing where it intended to lay off 300 or so from a staff of 450 or so. Currently there are multiple changes occurring in the company and the as reported in Section 8 future toxic usage are approximations only.  The company also used more nitric acid in 2011.  Typically precious metal scrap is sent to a refinery for metals recovery.  The refining cost is expensive and ties up precious metal while it is in the refining cycle.  The company started hydro refining precious metal by etching copper laminate from precious metal scrap using nitric acid and therefore the nitric acid usage and and the attendant nitrate compound byproduct increased significantly in 2011. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

61109CHMPR3910L	1311209063421	000079016	TRICHLOROETHYLENE	TRI	2011	CHEM PROCESSING INC	3910 LINDEN OAKS DR	ROCKFORD	WINNEBAGO	IL	61109			YES	NO	NO	NO								332813						42.21912	-89.02496	055413801										The increase of emissions from this chemical are attributed to a contaminant that was discovered in the degreaser from a customer's parts.  After investigation it was found that this contaminant was brought in on the oil of a job lot and decreased the efficiency of the degreaser by sticking to the water jacket and reducing the degreaser capacity to condense water.  This resulted in an increase in the acidity of the degreaser and a decrease in the efficiency.  A full cleanout was performed and waste trichloroethylene was shipped offsite.  This is shown in the increase of waste volume from 2010 levels.  No violation of the current Title V permit occurred, however this decreased efficiency caused the emissions from this chemical to approach the maximum permit levels.  An increase in the frequency of cleaning this equipment has been taken to insure that this equipment is running at design efficiency.	NO	CBERTRAND@CHEMPROCESSING.COM			NO

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 77571WTCCR9401S	1311209284405	007637072	BORON TRIFLUORIDE	TRI	2011	GULBRANDSEN TECHNOLOGIES INC	9401 STRANG RD	LA PORTE	HARRIS	TX	77571			YES	NO	NO	NO								325188						29.70183	-95.0758	102511594								GULBRANDSEN	102511594	Our site has had zero accidental releases. The only release we have comes from our scrubber that is 99.9999% efficient. That produced less than one Lb of boron trifluoride being release into the air the entire year. No other waste streams were generated and no BF3 entered land nor water streams. BF3 is a gas.  We react BF3 with water in our scrubber to neutralize it making it non hazardous.  This waste accumulates and is shipped off to a company that injects this neutralized waste into a well. It was calculated that 3,615Lb BF3 was inside our scrubber tank at one point in 2011 and shipped for disposal.  2010 the scrubber was not emptied nor did it have it's contents shipped away to be deep well injected.  That is the reason why 2011 had a higher amount of treated waste generated since in 2010 we didn't generate waste since it stayed in the system.  Our site does not make BF3 we just re package it for a few of our customers.	NO	EMEJIAS@GULBRANDSEN.COM			YES

On-going problem solving to improve first time yields is a contributing factor.  Employees identify problems in the process that cause a product to fall out or need repair, and then 'problem solve' to eliminate the root cause and prevent the problems from reoccuring when that job is run again.  This method of problem solving that drills down to a specific product and problem can prevent a knee jerk reaction to a problem that could potentially create problems for other products in the line. 23701SDTSC4000C	1311209078955	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2011	US COAST GUARD BASE PORTSMOUTH	4000 COAST GUARD BLVD	PORTSMOUTH	PORTSMOUTH (CITY)	VA	23703			YES	NO	YES	NO								928110						36.873566	-76.376961			VA4690320235						US DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY		As mentioned last year, Base Portsmouth is using a high efficiency vacuum for cleaning the concrete pad of the firing range. This has worked very well in reducing lead concentrations on the pad, which in turn minimizes the lead concentrations in the stormwater runoff. Regardless, periodic monitoring has shown very slight traces of particulate lead and dissolved lead in the stormwater runoff from the concrete pad. Hence the change in discharges to water bodies from "NA" to "1 to 10 lbs". In reviewing 2010 TRI data, a miscalculation was discovered. The fugitive air emissions for 2010 should have been 5.1805 lbs versus 4.1472 lbs. Instead of an increase from 2010 to 2011 as the report is showing, there should have been a decrease of 4%. Normally, the base sends out 2 shipments of lead to be recycled. During 2011, only 1 shipment went out, but on 1/12/12 a shipment went but that will be counted for 2012. Because of the timing of our shipments, it shows a decrease of 74.2% in our recycling. I expect 2012's recycling amount to be much higher. The waste transferred offsite doubled because wood support structures at the firing range containing lead had to be replaced. These lead containing timbers doubled our normal weight output of lead waste for the year.	YES	GENE.C.LEONARD@USCG.MIL			YES

7670WRGNSP182EA	1311209317763	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - WACO	1820 EAST HIGHWAY 6	WACO	MCLENNAN	TX	76704			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						31.55835	-97.09814	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

7670WRGNSP182EA	1311209317775	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - WACO	1820 EAST HIGHWAY 6	WACO	MCLENNAN	TX	76704			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						31.55835	-97.09814	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

Because of that we had to go back 5 years and make up for lost time. 7340WRGNSP25REF	1311209317751	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC  - ARDMORE	2500 REFINERY RD.	ARDMORE	CARTER	OK	73401			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						34.20148	-97.11678	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 61856VBNCR226WE	1311209078637	000110543	N-HEXANE	TRI	2011	VIOBIN USA DIV OF MCSHARES INC	226 W LIVINGSTON ST	MONTICELLO	PIATT	IL	61856			YES	NO	NO	NO								311211						40.02713	-88.57475	061096483								MCSHARES INC	065240319	As noted in in the Data Quality Alert Message for RY2011 there is an 89.8% change in the waste from the previous RY2010.  In the RY2011 there was a significant increase in our customer orders.  Because of the increase in orders we started running both the Continuous and Batch Plant Extractors Simultaneously.    We do not normally operate our Extraction Plants simultaneously or on an alternating back and forth production schedule.  Doing this higher level of production along with the starting-up and shutting-down or simultaneously running the Extractors has contributed to the overall increase of fugitive emissions.    In addition, to the increased production and the alternating production schedule; the Batch Plant carbon beds became saturated and had to be changed with fresh carbon; it was also discovered at that time that two of the carbon system valves were not functioning correctly.    I believe that the increase in emissions is directly related to the issues with the Batch Plant.  The Batch Plant has been completely inspected and all systems are now functioning within prescribed standards.	NO	ROGERMOHR@VIOBINUSA.COM			NO

46517GLBLG58190	1311209129271	000100425	STYRENE	TRI	2011	GLOBAL COMPOSITES INC PLANT 4	58190 COUNTY RD 3	ELKHART	ELKHART	IN	46517			YES	NO	NO	NO								326199						41.649556	-86.019805									GLOBAL COMPOSITES INC		This facility had increases not only in production but also in the content of the HAPs in the materials.  Our products are custom designed and many of our customers changed from using White lower HAP containing products to Various Colors which have higher HAP contents than the plain whites. Although the HAP contents have increased our facility still operates will within the emission limitations for HAP's listed in EPA's NESHAP for Reinforced Plastics.  This would be the explanation for why the emissions might have increased slightly more than the production ratio.  Also the part sizes seem to be getting larger. 19801NRMCF500OL	1311209131895	000075092	DICHLOROMETHANE	TRI	2011	NORAMCO INC	500 SWEDES LANDING RD	WILMINGTON	NEW CASTLE	DE	19801			YES	NO	NO	NO								325411						39.73773	-75.53979	057234486								SK CAPITAL PARTNERS		The method of calculation of the quantity that was sent to the POTW and Offsite fuel blending were respectively estimated using the stripping efficiency of the wastewater pre-treatment plant steam stripping operation.  Previously, the mean of the concentration in the effluent from the wastewater pre-treatment operation and the mean of the concentration in the offsite fuel blend waste stream were used to estiamte the quantities.  After a review of the spread of the concentration values used to estimate the mean, it has been determined that this mean is not truly representative of the quantities.   During the previous year Dichloromethane was recovered and in some situations reused  in the process.  During 2011, Dichoromethane was not reused in the process and this resulted in an increased total usage of the fresh chemical sitewide for the year.  Most of the dichloromethane used in the process ends up in the wastewater stream. This is evident in the data in this report as follows; The  facility is reporting a 204.4% change in the total quantity of production-related waste (sum of Sections 8.1 through 8.7, Column B) of Dichloromethane as compared to the prior year. The prior year's form for this chemical included 80361.22 lbs of total production-related waste and the current year's form includes 244622.0 lbs of total production-related waste. ARDMORE	CARTER	OK	73401			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						34.20148	-97.11678	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

44509WLKRW912SA	1311209678453	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	CRAFCO INC-YOUNGSTOWN	912 SALT SPRINGS RD	YOUNGSTOWN	MAHONING	OH	44509			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						41.113286	-80.682793	084465145		OHD074548694		OHR000002				ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Crafco's toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  Crafco has not previously submitted a report for this facility because Crafco did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While Crafco does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, Crafco employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

44509WLKRW912SA	1311209678465	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	CRAFCO INC-YOUNGSTOWN	912 SALT SPRINGS RD	YOUNGSTOWN	MAHONING	OH	44509			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						41.113286	-80.682793	084465145		OHD074548694		OHR000002				ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Crafco's toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  Crafco has not previously submitted a report for this facility because Crafco did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While Crafco does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, Crafco employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. Although there is no definitive reason behind the reduction, there was a modification to the method of handling the solids from the wastewater clarifiers @ 6 months prior to the reporting year 2011. Prior to that time, the clarifier solids were reintroduced into the headworks of the anaerobic lagoons & removed from the lagoon bottom throughout the year to a sludge storage basin.. A redirecting of the solids directly to the sludge storage pond has resulted in additional treatment capacity in the anaerobic lagoons which may have affected nitrate compound generation. 6704WRGNSP8EAST	1311209333931	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - EL DORADO	800 EAST 10TH STREET	EL DORADO	BUTLER	KS	67042			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						37.810133	-96.834765	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			NO

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count.For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

44115MTLSP2800E	1311209671229	007697372	NITRIC ACID	TRI	2011	GOODRICH PLATING OPS	2800 E.33RD ST	CLEVELAND	CUYAHOGA	OH	44115			YES	NO	NO	NO								332813						41.48246	-81.66666	780459749								UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP	001344142	Nitric acid is used to periodically clean certain plating tanks.  When not in use for cleaning, it is returned to a holding tank.  When contaminants render the nitric acid incapable of further cleaning potential, we ship it to a hazardous waste vendor.  Releases are counted only when we dispose of the waste.  Because many months, exceeding even a year, can pass before it becomes necessary to dispose of the waste, releases of nitric acid can vary widely from one year to the next. 37405RGNTR617TE	1311209622188	000100425	STYRENE	TRI	2011	ERGON TERMINALING INC-CHATTANOOGA	617 TERMINAL RD	CHATTANOOGA	HAMILTON	TN	37405			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						35.095979	-85.329085	096382585								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Terminaling, Inc. (ETI) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  ETI has not recently submitted a report for this facility because ETI did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While ETI does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, ETI employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 46231QMTCN7870W	1311209565403	N090	CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS(EXCEPT CHROMITE ORE MINED IN THE TRANSVAAL REGION)	TRI	2011	QUEMETCO INC	7870 W MORRIS ST	INDIANAPOLIS	MARION	IN	46231			YES	NO	NO	NO								331492						39.755554	-86.300056	008347197								QUEXCO INC	099710303	Reporting facility is a secondary lead smelting facility that recycles spent "lead acid" batteries and scrap containing lead to produce a finished product (pure lead and/or numerous lead alloys)  that is used primarily by manufacturers to produce new batteries.  Spent batteries (typically contain 58-63% lead content) and scrap (0-100% lead content) are the main raw materials that are smelted and refined.  Due to the presence of trace alloys and/or contaminants a disposable slag is generated that requires landfill disposal since no beneficial use (redo, reuse, recycle) is possible in order to prevent future environmental issues from developing. 79120SDPRTUSHIG	1311209390970	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2011	US DOE PANTEX PLANT	955 FM-2373	PANHANDLE	CARSON	TX	79068			YES	NO	YES	NO								325920						35.307037	-101.559419									US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY		Explanation for changes in release quantities: (1) During calendar year 2011, Pantex held the Security Protection Officer Team competition that included competitive shooting by numerous teams which used additional lead ammunition. (2) Also, during calendar year 2011, a remediation project was implemented at the Firing Range which generated a significant amount of lead waste that significantly increased the lead release quantities at Pantex.  The outdoor portion of the Firing Range at the Pantex Plant is used by Security personnel for firearms practice and training.  The Firing Range has several earthen berms that bullets are fired into during training exercises.  These berms are covered with a layer of dolomite, and most of the lead bullets are captured in the dolomite layer.  After a period of 10 to 15 years, the dolomite becomes saturated with lead bullets and must be replaced.  The replacement is necessary because bullets can ricochet from the saturated dolomite, causing a safety hazard to Security personnel.    Normally, the lead-contaminated dolomite would be completely removed and disposed of as hazardous waste and then new dolomite would be purchased and applied to the berms to replace the removed material.  For this project, Pantex personnel were determined to find a way to recycle the large quantity of material to be removed from the berms.  A contractor was located with capabilities to filter and clean the dolomite so that a majority of the material could be recovered and reapplied to the berms.  This approach proved to be very successful both in reducing costs and the quantity of hazardous waste generated.   Replacement of the dolomite without recycling would have resulted in the generation of 1,440 tons of hazardous waste.  By implementing this recycling project to filter and reuse the majority of the dolomite, only 24 tons of waste were generated and disposed.  This represents a 98% reduction in hazardous waste and a corresponding cost savings of $422,800 in reduced shipping and disposal costs.  By reusing the filtered dolomite, Pantex also avoided purchasing approximately 1,500 tons of new dolomite for an additional cost savings of $28,365.  By taking the initiative for sustainability and cost effectiveness, the Pantex team involved with this project was successful in keeping 1,416 tons of hazardous waste out of a landfill while reducing costs by more than $450,000.	YES	JACK.ZANGER@NPO.DOE.GOV			YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 20771NSGDDGREEN	1311209694722	000075456	CHLORODIFLUOROMETHANE	TRI	2011	NASA GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER	GREENBELT RD	GREENBELT	PRINCE GEORGES	MD	20771			YES	NO	YES	NO								927110						38.99124	-76.85546			MD9800013865		MD0067482						In CY11 Goddard Space Flight Center (GSFC) experienced several events that caused GSFC to purchase and install new Chlorodifluoromethane (HCFC-22) that normally would have been recovered and reused.  The cause of one release was a combination of high temperature and a faulty valve and/or gasket on a recovery tank, resulting in the purchase of 6,000 pounds of new HCFC-22 to replace the released HCFC-22 which had been recovered from equipment in preparation for repairs. In addition, contaminated HCFC-22 from another piece of equipment was sent off-site for recycling resulting in the use of 3,500 pounds of new HCFC-22 to clean and replace the HCFC-22 that was contaminated.  In this case there was no release to the environment, the entire contents of the chiller and recovery tank were sent off-site for recycling. Under normal operating conditions we would expect to use no more than 500 pounds of HCFC-22 to recharge each chiller resulting in an annual usage of about 3,000 pounds per year.  When a leak is discovered that cannot be quickly repaired, the chiller is evacuated to a recovery tank and the recovered HCFC-22 is reused. This year we had two abnormal events that caused us to exceed our activity threshold for this chemical.  We do not anticipate this happening again in the future.	YES	LIXA.E.RODRIGUEZ-RAMON@NASA.GOV			NO

19605KCHMT3847P	1311209262183	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - READING	3847 POTTSVILLE PIKE	READING	BERKS	PA	19605			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						40.392593	-75.932153	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 9233WCRFCN14142	1311209622099	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	CRAFCO, INC. - FONTANA	14142 WHITTRAM AVENUE	FONTANA	SAN BERNARDINO	CA	92335			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						34.09566	-117.49713									ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

In past years we were not tracking the amount of chromium going to the landfill. 84006KNNCT12300	1311209758010	N078	CADMIUM COMPOUNDS	TRI	2011	KENNECOTT UTAH COPPER MINE CONCENTRATORS & POWER PLANT	8362 WEST 10200 SOUTH	BINGHAM CANYON	SALT LAKE	UT	84006			YES	NO	NO	NO								212234	221112					40.516667	-112.15	619968779								RIO TINTO AMERICA INC		With each TRI reporting period, small changes in TRI constituent concentrations may be observed throughout the various plant processes resulting in significant implications for overall reported constituents when large tonnages are moved.    For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

84087SMMTR991W1	1311209262106	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - WOODS CROSS	991 W 1500 S	WOODS CROSS	DAVIS	UT	84087			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						40.87471	-111.907057	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases. This change required a transport system which included a collection hopper with load cells.  While the dry injection system was disbanded after 3 weeks due to major safety & production issues, it did allow us to collect accurate dust generation data for an extended period of time. 6132WMRQSN11953	1311209844683	000075070	ACETALDEHYDE	TRI	2011	MARQUIS ENERGY LLC	11953 PRAIRIE INDUSTRIAL PKWY	HENNEPIN	PUTNAM	IL	61327			YES	NO	NO	NO								325193						41.27697	-89.31724	783374692										Acetaldehyde is produced during fermentation, and off gases are sent to a CO2 scrubber for removal of acetaldehyde.  Sodium bisulfite is injected into the scrubber water to further reduce acetaldehyde emissions.  Acetaldehyde within the scrubber liquid stream is recycled back to the cook water tank for use in fermentation.  During fermentation, the yeast used to convert the sugar to ethyl alcohol metabolizes the acetaldehyde.  Acetaldehyde emissions are also generated during wet feed drying.  Emissions are reduced by the thermal   oxidizers.  The change in potential release from 2010 to 2011 reporting year is due to emissions testing that was conducted in January of 2012 at maximum production rate, and site specific emissions factors are based on emissions during testing. 6704WRGNSP8EAST	1311209333943	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - EL DORADO	800 EAST 10TH STREET	EL DORADO	BUTLER	KS	67042			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						37.810133	-96.834765	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

23231NBSCB6002S	1311209270420	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2011	MONDELEZ GLOBAL LLC	6002 S LABURNUM AVE	RICHMOND	RICHMOND	VA	23231			YES	NO	NO	NO								311821						37.493256	-77.353127	078605713								MONDELEZ INTERNATIONAL INC	877147228	Ammonia from these reactions is created as a byproduct of baking.    Ammonium Bicarbonate to Ammonia Conversion = NH4HCO3 + &#8593;= NH3 + CO2 +H2O  The molecular weight of ammonium bicarbonate NH4HC03 = 79. The MW of ammonia NH3 = 17. 17/79 = .215  To determine the amount of ammonia that is released, multiply the total pounds of ammonium bicarb by .215    Diammonium Phosphate (Ammonium Phosphate, Dibasic to Ammonia Conversion  (NH4)2HPO4 &#8593;-heat= 2NH3 + H3PO4  The molecular weight of Diammonium Phosphate (NH4)2HP04 = 132  The MW of ammonia NH3 '" 17, (17x2)/132 '" .2576  To determine the amount of ammonia that is released, multiply the total pounds of Diammonium Phosphate by .2576	NO	GUILLERMO.HARO@MDLZ.COM			NO

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-ME software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.    With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-to-year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM			YES

Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		YES

76011BRRYM3800E	1311209708078	000075092	DICHLOROMETHANE	TRI	2011	BERRYMAN PRODUCTS INC	3800 E RANDOL MILL RD	ARLINGTON	TARRANT	TX	76011			YES	NO	NO	NO								325998						32.75046	-97.04167	055326508		TXD055326508								The release figure of 23,700 Lb is not in fact accurate; it should be lower, probably much lower.  We implemented a new process last year in which we bring neat DCM on-site and blend finished goods with it (rather than purchase pre-blend chemicals) in order to save money.    However, we found out after several sizable batches that our metering system was not properly registering DCM.  In fact, we were overpumping, i.e. using more than we anticipated.  Unforuntely, our quality control checks were not able to detect this, and these excess usages were not discovered in time to fully and accurately be able to account for them.  As such, they show up as releases when in fact for the most part they were not releases/emissions at all.	NO	ETORRES@BERRYMANPRODUCTS.COM			NO

3885WRGNSP35CR3	1311209621945	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - YELLOW CREEK	35 CR 370	IUKA	TISHOMINGO	MS	38852			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121	424710					34.975737	-88.240143	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

(ETI) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  ETI has not recently submitted a report for this facility because ETI did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While ETI does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, ETI employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

29044STHCR142WA	1311209841170	N040	BARIUM COMPOUNDS	TRI	2011	WATEREE STATION - SCE& G	142 WATEREE STATION RD	EASTOVER	RICHLAND	SC	29044			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						33.826704	-80.622177	007919517								SCANA CORP	101904845	Aerosol corrections: at wateree station a single sulfur removal scrubber is shared between the two units.  Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		YES

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 29044STHCR142WA	1311209841269	007664939	SULFURIC ACID (1994 AND AFTER "ACID AEROSOLS" ONLY)	TRI	2011	WATEREE STATION - SCE& G	142 WATEREE STATION RD	EASTOVER	RICHLAND	SC	29044			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						33.826704	-80.622177	007919517								SCANA CORP	101904845	Aerosol corrections: at wateree station a single sulfur removal scrubber is shared between the two units.  Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		NO

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

The reported glycol ether emission release is based on two values.  The first value is the amount of glycol ethers in raw material paints/coatings used to coat the new and reconditioned drums multiplied by the content concentration.  The other value is based on the amount of glycol ethers received from other companies that sent glycol ethers to the facility.  The offsite received glycol ethers are due to the residual amounts in the empty containers sent to the facility.  These containers are reconditioned.  The received empty containers are washed and the run through a dryer oven.  The wash/incineration emissions from the residual amounts of glycol ethers in the used containers go to stacks S50, S51, and/or S53.  The sending companies should use M54 for Type of Waste Treatment/Disposal/Recycling/Energy Recovery (enter code) in 6.2.C.	NO	MFURGASON@MASDINC.COM			NO

FOR RY2009, RY2010 AND RY2011, SANTA ROSA LEAD PRODUCTS IS BELOW THE MAN-HOUR THRESHOLD AND IS NOT REQUIRED TO FILE TRI FORM R TO THE EPA, BUT WE HAVE CONTINUED TO FILE REGARDLESS. ---------- Part II, SECTION 6.2.  Submit additional optional information about Other Off-site Transfers, Basis of Estimate: BASED ON KNOWLEDGE OF MATERIAL TRANSFERRED OFF-SITE, WEIGHT OF LEAD COMPOUNDS (IN POUNDS) IS 1% OR LESS OF TOTAL WEIGHT SHIPPED/TRANSFERRED. ---------- SECTION 8.11.  Submit additional optional information on source reduction, recycling, or pollution control activities: BASED ON 40 CFR PART 261.4(A)(13), EXCLUDED SCRAP METAL (PROCESSED SCRAP METAL AND UNPROCESSED PROMPT SCRAP METAL) BEING RECYCLED ARE NOT CONSIDERED SOLID WASTES.  "SCRAP METAL" IS DEFINED BY 40 CFR PART 261.1(A)(6) AS BITS AND PIECES OF METAL PARTS (E.G.,) BARS, TURNINGS, RODS, SHEETS, WIRE) OR METAL PIECES THAT MAY BE COMBINED TOGETHER WITH BOLTS OR SOLDERING (E.G., RADIATORS, SCRAP AUTOMOBILES, RAILROAD BOX CARS), WHICH WHEN WORN OR SUPERFLUOUS CAN BE RECYCLED.  AT THE SANTA ROSA LEAD PRODUCTS FACILITY, SCRAP LEAD IS GENERATED IN THE FORM OF SMALL SCRAP SHEETS FROM CUTTING PROCESSES, LEAD DUST FROM GRINDING OPERATIONS, AND EXCESS SOLDER FROM SOLDERING ACTIVITIES.  THIS SCRAP LEAD IS COLLECTED AND CONTAINERIZED IN 55-GALLON METAL CONTAINERS (DRUMS) AND SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO INDUSTRIES FACILITY IN GRANITE CITY, ILLINOIS, AND/OR IS COLLECTED IN "GAYLORD" CRATES AND SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO INDUSTRIES FACILITY IN BIRMINGHAM, ALABAMA, WHERE IT IS RE-MELTED/RECYCLED.  THIS CRATED SCRAP LEAD IS ALSO SOLD AS A COMMODITY TO SEVERAL CUSTOMERS.  IN 2011 APPROXIMATELY 43,374 TOTAL POUNDS OF SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED FROM THE SANTA ROSA LEAD PRODUCTS FACILITY: APPROXIMATELY 1,311 POUNDS OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO FACILITY IN GRANITE CITY, ILLINOIS, APPROXIMATELY 6,263 POUNDS OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SHIPPED TO THE MAYCO FACILITY IN BIRMINGHAM, AL, AND APPROXIMATELY 35,800 POUNDS OF THIS SCRAP LEAD WAS SOLD AS A COMMODITY.	NO	JEREMY@SANTAROSALEAD.COM			YES

84006KNNCT8362W	1311209869914	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2011	KENNECOTT UTAH COPPER SMELTER & REFINERY	12000 WEST 2100 SOUTH & 11500 W 2100 S	MAGNA	SALT LAKE	UT	84044			YES	NO	NO	NO								331411						40.735345	-112.124401	619968779								RIO TINTO AMERICA INC		With each TRI reporting period, small changes in TRI constituent concentrations may be observed throughout the various plant processes resulting in significant implications for overall reported constituents when large tonnages are moved.  For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		NO

84006KNNCT8362W	1311209869977	001319773	CRESOL (MIXED ISOMERS)	TRI	2011	KENNECOTT UTAH COPPER SMELTER & REFINERY	12000 WEST 2100 SOUTH & 11500 W 2100 S	MAGNA	SALT LAKE	UT	84044			YES	NO	NO	NO								331411						40.735345	-112.124401	619968779								RIO TINTO AMERICA INC		With each TRI reporting period, small changes in TRI constituent concentrations may be observed throughout the various plant processes resulting in significant implications for overall reported constituents when large tonnages are moved.  For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		NO

67801KCHMT2600B	1311209622289	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - DODGE CITY	2600 BUTTER & EGG RD	DODGE CITY	FORD	KS	67801			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						37.748333	-99.9775	122695240		KSD981117963						ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 93446ZRNND1747C	1311209649351	007440508	COPPER	TRI	2011	ZURN INDUSTRIES WILKINS DIV	1747 COMMERCE WAY	PASO ROBLES	SAN LUIS OBISPO	CA	93446			YES	NO	NO	NO								332919						35.610249	-120.652365	828926555								REXNORD CORP	828926555	Changes made from prior years release; reclassification of scrap articles such that they are no longer reported:  Fresno Valves Foundry remelts the material.  Per "1998 EPCRA Section 313 Questions and Answers",      item 588, page 192, ". . . the [constituent] in the metal scraps is not being recovered but merely melted and reused.  Therefore, the amount of the toxic chemical int eh metal scraps would not be reportable in Part II, Sections     6.2 or 8 of the Form R."  Therefore, the quantity should be considered as part of the threshold determination      to determine if the chemical is reportable.  However, the amount going to Fresno is not reportable.            Standard Industries takes bronze cuttings, turnings and chips and sells to a bronze ingot manufacturer.  The      chips are remelted into ingot bars, while retaining the original alloy composition without alloys being separated.      Per "1998 EPCRA Section 313 Questions and Answers", item 588, page 192, ". . . the [constituent] in the metal     scraps is not being recovered but merely melted and reused.  Therefore, the amount of the toxic chemical in the     metal scraps would not be reportable in Part II, Sections 6.2 or 8 of the Form R."  Therefore, the quantity should     be considered as part of the threshold determination to determine if the chemical is reportable.  However,       the amount going to Standard Industries is not reportable.	NO	ED.STETTLER@ZURNWILKINS.COM			YES

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 68933SDGRCSTATE	1311209602604	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2011	U.S. USDA AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH SERVICE RLHUSMARC	STATE SPUR 18D	CLAY CENTER	CLAY	NE	689330166			YES	NO	YES	NO								541712						40.524773	-98.140945									US DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE		Federal agencies are required to comply with the emergency planning and community right-To-Know act of 1986 (Epcra) and the pollution prevention act of 1990 (Ppa).  Requirements for federal agencies to report toxic release inventory (Tri) data began with 1994 data.  A report is required for any listed toxic chemical that is manufactured or processed at a facility in excess of 25,000 pounds during the course of a calender year; or if the quantity of a listed toxic chemical that is otherwise used at a facility exceeds 10,000 pounds during the course of a calendar year.  Entities other than the federal government are required to report if they have a standard industrial code (Sic) of 20-39.  Federal agencies must report regardless of sic code.  Anhydrous ammonia is included as a toxic chemical on the reportable list.  Anhydrous ammonia was used at the roman l.  Hruska u.S.  Meat animal research center as fertilizer for production of corn for livestock feed.  It is no longer used.  Agricultural use of anhydrous ammonia by non-Federal agency consumers would not be required to report.	YES				NO

67801KCHMT2600B	1311209622291	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - DODGE CITY	2600 BUTTER & EGG RD	DODGE CITY	FORD	KS	67801			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						37.748333	-99.9775	122695240		KSD981117963						ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO	 	
93446ZRNND1747C	1311209649363	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2011	ZURN INDUSTRIES WILKINS DIV	1747 COMMERCE WAY	PASO ROBLES	SAN LUIS OBISPO	CA	93446			YES	NO	NO	NO								332919						35.610249	-120.652365	828926555								REXNORD CORP	828926555	Regarding the change in calculating release quantities; scrap articles have been reclassified and are no longer reported:  Fresno Valves Foundry remelts the material.  Per "1998 EPCRA Section 313 Questions and Answers",      item 588, page 192, ". . . the [constituent] in the metal scraps is not being recovered but merely melted and reused.      Therefore, the amount of the toxic chemical int eh metal scraps would not be reportable in Part II, Sections      6.2 or 8 of the Form R."  Therefore, the quantity should be considered as part of the threshold determination      to determine if the chemical is reportable.  However, the amount going to Fresno is not reportable.            Standard Industries takes bronze cuttings, turnings and chips and sells to a bronze ingot manufacturer.  The      chips are remelted into ingot bars, while retaining the original alloy composition without alloys being separated.      Per "1998 EPCRA Section 313 Questions and Answers", item 588, page 192, ". . . the [constituent] in the metal       scraps is not being recovered but merely melted and reused.  Therefore, the amount of the toxic chemical in the      metal scraps would not be reportable in Part II, Sections 6.2 or 8 of the Form R."  Therefore, the quantity should      be considered as part of the threshold determination to determine if the chemical is reportable.  However,       the amount going to Standard Industries is not reportable.	NO	ED.STETTLER@ZURNWILKINS.COM			YES

84006KNNCT8362W	1311209869953	N090	CHROMIUM COMPOUNDS(EXCEPT CHROMITE ORE MINED IN THE TRANSVAAL REGION)	TRI	2011	KENNECOTT UTAH COPPER SMELTER & REFINERY	12000 WEST 2100 SOUTH & 11500 W 2100 S	MAGNA	SALT LAKE	UT	84044			YES	NO	NO	NO								331411						40.735345	-112.124401	619968779								RIO TINTO AMERICA INC		With each TRI reporting period, small changes in TRI constituent concentrations may be observed throughout the various plant processes resulting in significant implications for overall reported constituents when large tonnages are moved.  For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		YES

For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		NO

38113RGNSP1655H	1311209524800	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ARMOR INC-MEMPHIS	1655 HARBOR AVE	MEMPHIS	SHELBY	TN	38113			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						35.10106	-90.1074	122695240								ERGON INC	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Armor (EA) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  (EA) has not previously submitted a report for this facility because (EA) did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While (EA) does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, (EA) employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.
