95903SDDSFENDOF	1311209720349	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2011	U.S. DOD, USAF, BEALE AFB	9 CES/CEIE 6601 B ST	BEALE AFB	YUBA	CA	95903			NO	YES	YES	NO								928110						39.089167	-121.424444			CA7570024508		CA0110299				US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE		The small amount of lead (0.2 lbs) reported as transferred off-site in section 6.2 was the result of 2,640 lbs of lead-contaminated wood that had been used as targets at the rifle range.  A representative sample of the contaminated wood underwent laboratory analysis and was determined to have a lead content of 90.4 mg/kg.  Because off-site disposal of this type could conceivably occur again, it was not reported as a one-time event not associated with production processes in section 8.8; but 0 lbs are indicated for the following year and second following year in section 8.1 because any such event is expected to occur rarely and on a non-scheduled/as-needed basis only.  The notable 30% reduction in the amount of reportable lead on the TRI Form R from RY2011, compared to RY2010, is due to improved data collection and more accurate metrics provided by the 9th Security Forces on the numbers of rounds expended at each of the installation ranges for the 2011 calendar year. Data provided were attributable to the non-exempt training activities of active-duty personnel.  In contrast with this reduction, the 3-fold increase in the amount of reportable lead indicated for the following year and the second following year in section 8.1 is expected as a result of a new course of fire order issued in 2012 that significantly increased the amount of military training activities being conducted at Beale AFB ranges. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 70669KRNSL3300B	1311210057853	007647010	HYDROCHLORIC ACID (1995 AND AFTER "ACID AEROSOLS" ONLY)	TRI	2011	LOUISIANA PIGMENT CO LP	3300 BAYOU D'INDE RD	WESTLAKE	CALCASIEU PARISH	LA	70669			YES	NO	NO	NO								325131						30.196389	-93.306944	809154958										The SARA Hotline was contacted on June 20, 2012 to discuss the treatment system for HCL that ends at the Off-Gas Incinerator (Section 7A.1A). In previous years the amount of HCL treated (reported in Section 8.6) has been incorrectly calculated because the treatment system took the HCL present from the Dust Cyclone to Incineration.  Therefore the amount of HCL treated in Section 8.6 incorrectly included the amount of HCL that was processed as a by-product. The Treatment System for HCL prior to emission to the atmosphere begins at the Caustic Scrubber and proceeds to incineration. Therefore, Section 7A has been changed to accurately reflect the Treatment System for HCL to Incineration and Section 8.6 is accurately reflects the amount of HCL remaining in the Off-Gas after HCL is removed from the Off-Gas, condensed to hydrochloric acid, and separated as a by-product. As a result, Section 8.6 is substantially lower than previously reported. Corrections to previous years are being submitted.	NO	TIM.HALL@LAPIGMENT.COM	RR5		NO

7350WRGNSP931SW	1311209262157	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - LAWTON	9301 SW KOCH ST.	LAWTON	COMANCHE	OK	73505			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						34.60236	-98.50481	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. Our shipment for recycling off-site in 2010 was done in December of 2010.  During 2011 we did not make a shipment .   We generate "Universal Waste" from manufacturing rejects and "spent" product returned to us for disposal.       We did not send out any manufacturing by-product or rejects for "OFF-SIGHT RECYCLING" in  2011. We will send out a shipment in 2012.  In addition, every 2-3 years we send out a tank of dirty Mercury to be recycled off-sight. This Mercury is generated during the production process, from small spills during the filling operation, or process mistakes that cause the Mercury to be too dirty to use in good product.  This tank of dirty Mercury is about 800 - 1000 pounds.  It is returned to our supplier to be recycled, cleaned and returned to us. We did not generate enough dirty material to send out a shipment in either of the last 2 years.	NO	MBREWERS@MDIUS.COM			YES

16029MGNTC900EA	1311210002034	007429905	ALUMINUM (FUME OR DUST)	TRI	2011	SPANG & CO MAGNETICS DIV	796 E BUTLER RD	EAST BUTLER	BUTLER	PA	16029			YES	NO	NO	NO								334419						40.87742	-79.847191	004340949								SPANG & CO	004340949	For the original TRI for RY-2011 that was submitted in 2012, I mis-interpretted the definition of "Threshold Limit" as meaning the total amount released to the environment as summarized in Section 8 of Form R.  For Aluminum (Fume or Dust) these totals were less than 25,000#, so I didn't submit a Form R.  But in completing the TRI for RY-2012, I discovered my error and confirmed that the actual definition of "Threshold Limit" is the total amount processed on site for the year.  Therefore, I am correcting my mistake and adding the Form R for Aluminum (Fume or Dust) for RY-2011 since it did in fact exceed the 25,000# "Threshold Limit" for that year. Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.|REV:The RCRA ID was incorrectly noted as "Not Applicable" in the original submittal. 78064RGNSP972ND	1311209506979	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - PLEASANTON	907 2ND ST	PLEASANTON	ATASCOSA	TX	78064			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						28.966991	-98.478904	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 53081JLFRN4243G	1311210296796	007439965	MANGANESE	TRI	2011	NEMAK USA INC-GATEWAY	4243 GATEWAY DR	SHEBOYGAN	SHEBOYGAN	WI	53081			YES	NO	NO	NO								331314						43.70818	-87.7526	047260591								NEMAK USA INC		Unlike most the metals used at this facility, Manganese falls under two TRI activity categories, both as 1) a process chemical (formulation component), and 2) otherwise use (manufacturing aid).  As 1) a process chemical, the % by weight is below the 1% de minimis, as 2) otherwise use the % by weight is above the 1% de minimis.    For the 2011 reporting year, "otherwise use" amounts of materials containing metal constituents qualified manganese for TRI reporting (where previous years' usage was such that  otherwise use for manganese was below the 10,000 lb/year threshold).  It is important to note that per TRI guidance, regardless that manganese qualifyied for only one of the two activities mentioned above, all releases and recycling represent both activities (total for the facility), not just for the qualifying activity. As a result, release and recycling amounts for the previous reporting year, 2010, should not be related or compared to either of the qualifying activity reporting thresholds (i.e. compared to the 25,000 process threshold, or 10,000 otherwise use threshold).	NO	CAROL.TSAGARAKIS@NEMAK.COM	RR5		YES

78064RGNSP972ND	1311209506993	N590	POLYCYCLIC AROMATIC COMPOUNDS	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - PLEASANTON	907 2ND ST	PLEASANTON	ATASCOSA	TX	78064			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121						28.966991	-98.478904	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. 29044STHCR142WA	1311209841194	N100	COPPER COMPOUNDS	TRI	2011	WATEREE STATION - SCE& G	142 WATEREE STATION RD	EASTOVER	RICHLAND	SC	29044			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						33.826704	-80.622177	007919517								SCANA CORP	101904845	Aerosol corrections: at wateree station a single sulfur removal scrubber is shared between the two units.  Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		YES

When working on our RY 2012 Form Rs (and using a different software package), we discovered that we had incorrectly calculated our emissions by using CEMS sulfur data instead of fuel sulfur data. Historically, and prior to 2010, we had utilized CEMS sulfur data for our release calculations; however, since our CEMS monitors are located post-scrubber, we should have started using fuel sulfur data in 2010.	NO	DAVID.GAIER@NRG.COM	RR4		NO

Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation. 98315NVLSBC8521	1311209709548	007439921	LEAD	PBT	2011	NAVAL BASE KITSAP BANGOR - RANGE ACTIVITIES	1101 TAUTOG CIRCLE	SILVERDALE	KITSAP	WA	983151087			NO	YES	YES	NO								928110						47.716667	-122.725			WA5170027291						US DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE		This Form R is being submitted for lead from Range Activities that are part of the overall facility.  DOD guidelines require separate reporting for lead utilized in range and non-range activities.  Range activities are located at two locations at the facility, an indoor small arms range and an Emergency OB/OD site.  The small arms range is located indoors and is equipped with bullet traps and pollution control devices for the building's exhaust ventilation.  The OB/OD site is a small emergency and training site with a Burn Pan.  Therefore, although range activities cause the otherwise use threshold quantitites for lead to be exceeded, due to the design of the facilities and procedures in place, very little lead is released to the environment.  All air and land release estimates were estimated using the DOD's TRI-DDS reporting tool for munitions and range activities.	YES	SILVIA.KLATMAN@NAVY.MIL			YES

EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.|REV:The RCRA ID was incorrectly noted as "Not Applicable" in the original submittal. Each unitS normal flue gas stream passes through the scrubber to a common stack.  The original individual units stacks remain such that flue gases can by-Pass the scrubber to allow for scrubber maintenance without impacting generation availability.  To calculate the aerosol discharge the by-Pass scrubber fraction, in addition to that of the common stack, is required.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the originally submitted by-Pass fraction (52%) was in error.  The correct fraction is 9.92%.  The resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.  Reportable metals corrections: to calculate the reportable metals the percentage of beneficially use ash is a factor in the calculation.  Our review of the 2011 TRI form r submittal has revealed that the beneficial use percentage we used (49%) was in error.  The correct percentage is 80% the resubmitted form rS reflect the changes in emissions.	NO	EBOOMHOWER@SCANA.COM	RR4		YES

NO	DAVID.GAIER@NRG.COM	RR4		YES

3885WRGNSP35CR3	1311209621933	000191242	BENZO(G,H,I)PERYLENE	PBT	2011	ERGON ASPHALT & EMULSIONS INC - YELLOW CREEK	35 CR 370	IUKA	TISHOMINGO	MS	38852			YES	NO	NO	NO								324121	424710					34.975737	-88.240143	122695240								ERGON INC.	087023743	Enclosed is Ergon Asphalt & Emulsions (EAE) toxic release inventory (TRI) report for Reporting Year 2011.  EAE has not previously submitted a report for this facility because EAE did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While EAE does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, EAE employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility.	NO	MARY.SNOW@ERGON.COM			NO

Small Arms Range - typical small arms training by firing various types of standard ammunition. Range is equipped with a state-of-the-art bullet trap that allows us to recover almost all of the lead discharged during training activities. This material is collected and sent to a local scrap metal recycling business for recycling purposes. 2. Lead-acid batteries are used in out training boats, engine labs, and vehicles. The expended lead-acid batteries are collected and shipped to a local scrap metal recycler for proper recycling.	YES	THOMAS.E.HOLLINBERGER@USCG.MIL			YES

(EA) has not previously submitted a report for this facility because (EA) did not have ten or more full-time equivalent employees at the facility to trigger a reporting obligation under Section 313 of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA).  While (EA) does not believe it had 10 or more full-time equivalent employees during the reporting year, it has become increasingly difficult to track and determine the employee count in the manner suggested in EPA's guidance.  For example, (EA) employees that are not "based" at the facility, and work with multiple facilities, do not track their hours on a facility by facility basis.  Finally, it is unclear which work performed by contractors should be included and excluded from the employee count. For these reasons, we have elected to begin submitting TRI reports for this facility unless and until we can develop an effective system for tracking hours spent by employees and nonemployee contractors at the facility. For example, a process that moves millions of tons of material with a constituent concentration change of a few parts per million may result in a significant increase or decrease in reported releases.  Such increases or decreases can easily fall outside of the 5% change specified within TRI-Me software and may spur additional clarification on how that change can occur.  With such small fluctuations in mineral concentrations in an ore body, such fluctuations are common and seen year-To-Year with TRI reporting.	NO	KYLE.BENNETT@RIOTINTO.COM	RR5		YES

Particulate production for 2010 was 644,774 lbs vs 1,488,639 lbs for 2011.   The amount of metals excavated from the surface impoundment to be disposed in the landfill is significantly higher in 2011 than 2010 because the amount of ash that was excavated in 2011 was 35.82 million pounds vs 19.19 million pounds in 2010. The excavations were performed in preparation of the shutdown of the Savannah River Site's (SRS) Powerhouse facility. A SRS Biomass Cogeneration Facility will replace the deteriorating and inefficient 1950s-era coal powerhouse and oil-fired boilers, and will generate an estimated $944 million in savings in energy, operation and maintenance costs over the duration of the contract. 11101CNSLD3854V	1311211935717	007664417	AMMONIA	TRI	2011	TRANSCANADA RAVENSWOOD POWER STATION	38-54 VERNON BLVD	LONG ISLAND CITY	QUEENS	NY	11101			YES	NO	NO	NO								221112						40.75855	-73.94499									TRANSCANADA LTD		Recently, we received a notification from EPA that the TC Ravenswoods TRI data for Ammonia did not match what the NEI had listed for our facility. Upon this notice, we reviewed all TRI data submitted since TransCanada acquired this facility in 2009. While the number listed in the notice from EPA is due to a new emissions factor which we have not taken into account in our resubmission of data, it did lead us to a closer inspection of previously submitted reports. In our review of our old CEMS data we noticed that there must have been an error in the algorithm that calculated our old data reports, since the Ammonia numbers were all rather low considering the use of SCR by our Combined Cycle facility. The CEMS software was changed in the end of 2011 and all subsequent data is correct. However, after an evaluation of the raw data from 2009 through 2011, we did notice that the Ammonia emissions from this facility were higher than what was previously reported. Therefore, we are now submitting corrected data for Ammonia for 2009, 2010 and 2011.	NO	TANJA.GRZESKOWITZ@ETHOSENERGYGROUP.COM	RR4		NO

Response to DQA regarding facility failure to submit a Form R for the prior reporting year: The facility did not previously submit Form R reports for chromium based on the conclusion that steel alloy items received and processed at the facility met the definition of an article and were exempt from reporting under 40 CFR Section 372.38(b). The correct value, based on source testing performed in 1996 for the relevant process line, is 78.1 lb/year as stack or point source air emissions, and not 8.12 lb/yr as previously identified. The RY 2013 Form R report includes the corrected, 78.1 lb/yr figure. Because the relevant molten lead process operates at mostly steady state conditions, estimated lead air emissions from this process are not expected to change significantly from year-to-year. As a result, the facility believes that the previously reported lead emission values are incorrect, and is revising and resubmitting its Form R reports for the past 5 years to reflect the 78.1 lb/year figure. 97321SYNTH1290I	1311211810294	000067561	METHANOL	TRI	2011	W R GRACE & CO-CONN	1290 INDUSTRIAL WAY SW	ALBANY	LINN	OR	97322			YES	NO	NO	NO								325411	325188	325199				44.62855	-123.10208									W.R.GRACE & CO. - CONN.	001367846	Before 2011, we generated local reports of chemical usage through a business software application.  These reports captured for multiple types of chemical usage at the facility, including production batches, lab use, and "miscellaneous" use (most significantly, for methanol used in reactor cleaning).  In 2012, we discovered that our report did not capture miscellaneous methanol usage, so we revised our tracking efforts to include this usage for 2012.  It was not until preparing the report for 2013 that we realized we had not made an adjustment for 2011.  Due to a software change in mid-2011, we did not realize the need to make this adjustment to our reporting system.  That year there were both SAP reports and a miscellaneous methanol report, so the partial omission wasnt obvious.  We now have a system in place to ensure that miscellaneous methanol is included in the annual usage data.	NO	CAROLYN.WESOLEK@GRACE.COM	RR5		NO

54487HRLYD426ES	1311214901694	000071363	N-BUTYL ALCOHOL	TRI	2011	H-D MOTOR CO-TOMAHAWK SOMO	426 E SOMO AVE	TOMAHAWK	LINCOLN	WI	54487			YES	NO	NO	NO								336991						45.47202	-89.72342	102224623		WID001780139						HARLEY-DAVIDSON MOTOR CO	102224623	H-D Motor Co - Tomahawk has prepared this 2011 Form R following the environmental compliance audit and voluntary disclosure of potential noncompliance with its prior TRI reporting for n-butyl alcohol consistent with the U.S.EPA "Audit Policy". In preparing the online Form R through the TRI-MEweb, H-D Motor Co - Tomahawk encountered a "bug" in the online form in Section 8 (Waste Management). Specifically, after completing the form, when checking for errors, an error was identified that values in sections 8.1b and 8.5 (a) needed to be greater than zero (which they already were) and (b) could not contain commas (a condition that could not be manually overridden). After consulting with the Form R Help Desk (Case no. 305,994), it was suggested that H-D Motor Co - Tomahawk simply "Use Current Year Quantities" and provide this narrative in Section 9.1. Actual values for field 8.1.b should be 9,376.7 (2012) and 13,151.6 (2013) and for field 8.5 should be 1,746.3 (2012) and 2,445.4 (2013).	NO	PATRICK.SLAATS@HARLEY-DAVIDSON.COM			NO
